figure_1.title: FIGURE 1.
figure_1.caption: Hendrick Goltzius (1558–1617) Apollo, about to entrust centaur Chiron with the education of Asclepius [Courtesy National Gallery of Art, Washington DC]

figure_2.title: FIGURE 2.
figure_2.caption: Rembrandt van Rijn, The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp, 1632 [Courtesy Mauritshuis, The Hague, the Netherlands]

figure_3.title: FIGURE 3.
figure_3.caption: Increase of "medical education" as words in journal article titles [Google Scholar]

claims.sentence: Mythology teaches us that the first renown medical student and educator, Asclepius, son of Apollo and Coronis, had been educated himself in the art of medicine by centaur Chiron, and had learned about healing and resurrection from a snake who became his company along with a magical rod (Figure 1).
Figure 2 shows professor Nicolaes Tulp (1593–1674), delivering a public dissection lecture at the Waag Anatomical Theater in Amsterdam.
A different proxy of growth is shown in Figure 3, comparable to graphs presented by Jason in 2018.

Mythology teaches us that the first renown medical student and educator, Asclepius, son of Apollo and Coronis, had been educated himself in the art of medicine by centaur Chiron, and had learned about healing and resurrection from a snake who became his company along with a magical rod (Figure 1).
Figure 2 shows professor Nicolaes Tulp (1593–1674), delivering a public dissection lecture at the Waag Anatomical Theater in Amsterdam.
A different proxy of growth is shown in Figure 3, comparable to graphs presented by Jason in 2018.
